briefOverview: Revelation identifying Christ and defining His gospel, calling a servant named James to repent, be baptized, and preach as part of a gathering to Ohio in preparation for the Lord’s coming.
summary: The Lord self-identifies as Jesus Christ, the light and life of the world, declaring that receiving His gospel is equivalent to receiving Him. He defines the gospel as repentance, baptism by water, and the baptism of fire and the Holy Ghost, the Comforter. Addressing His servant James, the Lord acknowledges past pride and rejection but promises deliverance, the Spirit, and a great work if James will arise, be baptized, and preach the fulness of the gospel to recover Israel and build Zion. James is directed not to the eastern countries but to go to Ohio, where a unique blessing awaits the assembled Saints and from which missionaries will go to all nations. Urging urgent labor, the Lord promises to stay judgment upon repentance, commands proclamation that the kingdom of heaven is at hand, and affirms that those baptized should receive the Holy Ghost and look for His coming, which is near though its exact time is unknown.
externalContext: This revelation was received in January 1831 through Joseph Smith during a period of early Latter-day Saint gathering to the Kirtland, Ohio area. The addressee is historically identified as James Covel (or Covill), a Methodist minister who initially covenanted to obey but soon drew back (see the companion text in Doctrine and Covenants 40). The move to Ohio coincided with significant conversions in the Kirtland region, where early Saints formed a nucleus for church development. The period was marked by the religious ferment of the Second Great Awakening, where themes of repentance, baptism, spiritual gifts, and imminent divine intervention were prominent.
externalReferences: The opening language echoes biblical Christology and Johannine themes: light shining in darkness and being uncomprehended, and believers receiving power to become the sons of God (John 1:5, 11–12), as well as Jesus as the “I AM” (Exodus 3:14) and the “light of the world” (John 8:12). The description of the gospel aligns with New Testament teachings on baptism by water and by the Holy Ghost (Matthew 3:11), reception of the Comforter (John 14:26), and conferral of the Holy Ghost by laying on of hands (Acts 8:14–17). The call to “wash away your sins” reflects Acts 22:16, and proclaiming “the kingdom of heaven is at hand” parallels early Gospel proclamations (Matthew 3:2). The urgency about the Lord’s coming and the statement that no one knows the day or hour mirror Jesus’ eschatological discourse (Matthew 24:36); the “pruning” metaphor resonates with the allegory of the olive tree’s last pruning in Jacob 5:61–62 (Book of Mormon).

sectionTitles.title: Call to James and Ohio Gathering
Urgent Mission and the Lord’s Coming

practicalQuestions: What would it look like for me to “receive” Christ’s gospel today in concrete, actionable ways?
Where might pride or the cares of the world be keeping me from responding to God’s present call?
How can I prepare myself to both be baptized (or renew my baptismal covenants) and to receive and live by the Holy Ghost?
What sacrifices am I willing to make to participate in building Zion and supporting God’s gathering work?
How can my preaching or sharing of faith balance urgent warning with hope and invitation?
In what ways can I labor so that God’s promised blessings to my community are realized rather than forfeited?
uncertainAreas: The text simply names the addressee as “James”; identifying him specifically as James Covel relies on external historical sources. The phrase “pruned for the last time” likely alludes to Jacob 5, but this is interpretive rather than explicit in the text. Timing and logistics of the move to Ohio are not detailed here beyond the directive itself.
